data.title: Big 12 Conference Football Previews For Aug. 30-31 Games
data.meta_description: Big 12 Conference Football Previews For Aug. 30-31 Games
data.text:
Aug. 26, 2003

Complete Preview Release in PDF Format

Download Free Acrobat Reader

Listen to this week's football coaches' teleconference

DALLAS - It's a case of "11 for the Big 12" Saturday and Sunday as all teams compete in 11 games (Nebraska and Oklahoma State begin intraconference activity in Lincoln Saturday) in the coming weekend.

The NU-OSU contest is not an anomaly for conference football openers, though. Saturday's regionally-televised matchup at 2:30 p.m. (CDT) from Memorial Stadium/Tom Osborne Field actually is the fifth Big 12 Conference encounter played in August. On Aug. 31, 1996, Kansas State began Big 12 football competition with a 21-14 home win over Texas Tech. Texas downed Missouri 40-10 in Austin that same date.

On Aug. 30, 1997-the co-earliest starting date in league annals-Oklahoma State defeated Iowa State 21-14 in Ames while last year on Aug. 31 ISU toppled Kansas 45-3 in a national telecast (Fox Sports Net) to open conference contests.

The full-slate action this week, featuring six telecasts, starts at 11 a.m. (CDT) with a split-national telecast between Missouri and Illinois of the Big Ten Conference at St. Louis' Edward Jones Dome. It concludes with the Texas-New Mexico State game at 6 p.m. (CDT) Sunday with a Fox Sports Net national broadcast.

Here are capsule previews for the 11 games involving Big 12 Conference teams Saturday and Sunday:

MISSOURI vs. ILLINOIS

11 a.m. (CDT), Edward Jones Dome (66,965)

St. Louis, Mo., ABC Split National Telecast

Records & Rankings

Missouri - 5-7, 2-6 Big 12 Conference in 2002, RV in AP, ESPN/USA TODAY

Illinois - 5-7, 4-4 Big Ten Conference, RV in ESPN/USA TODAY

The Series

Missouri leads 12-7

At Columbia: MU leads 5-1

At Champaign: Series tied 5-5

At Neutral Sites: MU leads 2-1

Last Time Out:

Aug. 31, 2002: Missouri 33, Illinois 20 (at St. Louis)

Notes:

The teams play for the second consecutive year at the Edward Jones Dome-site of the 1996 and 1998 Dr Pepper Big 12 Football Championships. Missouri has built a 12-7 advantage over the Fighting Illini, and the teams are meeting for the second time in the EJD. They previously played at Busch Stadium in 1969 and at Exposition Park at St. Louis in 1896. This carries on a longstanding tradition of MU and Big Ten matchups. The Tigers are 39-56-4 in 99 previous games with Big Ten opposition while the latter league is a composite 297-190-20 in 507 contests with Big 12 opponents. Missouri's most recent game with a Big Ten foe was last season's win over UI while that was also the latest Illinois-Big 12 skirmish.

The Coaches

Missouri: Gary Pinkel (Kent State, 1975)

82-51-3 (13th season) overall

9-14 (2nd season) at Missouri

1-0 vs. Illinois

1-0 in bowl games

Illinois: Ron Turner (Pacific, 1977)

38-42 (8th season) overall

31-38 (7th season) at Illinois

0-1 vs. Missouri

1-1 in bowl games

Missouri Quick Hits

-The Tigers are 71-37-4 in their previous 112 season openers and now have started the campaign within the state of Missouri in each of the last seven years.

-Pinkel is 24th on the list of active Division I-A head coaches with his 82 triumphs.

-MU jumped from 88th (21.8 points per game) to 36th (30 points per contest) nationally in scoring offense from 2001 to '02.

-Mizzou QB Brad Smith is the only returnee with game experience after Kirk Farmer completed his eligibility last year; WR Justin Gage also was a backup quarterback for the Tigers in 2000.

Illinois Quick Hits

-Turner is the younger brother of longtime NFL offensive coordinator Norv Turner.

-The Illini face Illinois State of the Gateway Conference and Pacific-10 Conference contenders UCLA and California before turning their attention fulltime to Big Ten opposition.

-Illinois enters the 2003 campaign with a composite football record of 541-464-50-39th among current Division I-A programs.

-UI also is 6-8 in 14 bowl appearances and has played in seven postseason contests since 1990.

Missouri Key Individuals

Brad Smith, So., Quarterback

-Preseason All-America in several publications; 2002 Freshman Player of the Year in Offense in three different surveys.

-Named National Offensive Player of the Week for last year's 15-for-26 passing (152 yards) and 18-carry, 138-yard rushing showing in MU's 33-20 win over the Illini last August.

A.J. Ricker, Sr., Center

-Standout blocker who helped Tigers raise their scoring average 8.2 points per game from 2001 to 2002.

-Preseason All-Big 12 choice from the Houston, Texas, area with 30-plus career starts.

James Kinney, Jr., Linebacker

-One of the Top 10 individual tacklers in Big 12 as a sophomore with 148 stops to pace the Tigers.

-Had 11 tackles for loss, six quarterback sacks, one pass interception, and -73 yards on his 17 total hits behind the line.

Illinois Key Individuals

Jon Beuter, Sr., Quarterback

-One of the Big Ten's leading passers last year with 193-for-327 passing, 2,511 yards and 21 touchdowns.

-Completed 59 percent of his aerials and finished 19th nationally with 228.3 yards per game.

Marc Jackson, Sr., Strong Safety

-Team's leading returning tackler with 67 stops, three fumble recoveries, and one TFL in 2002.

-Possible All-Big Ten contender after showing ability to defend against opponents' toughest receivers.

Carey Davis, Sr., Fullback

-One of the top fullback-pass receivers in Division I-A.

-Paces all receivers' returnees for the 2003 Illini after making 29 catches for 201 yards, a 6.9 average and long gainer of 23 yards last season.

The Broadcast

Mike Kelly, Chris Gervino and John Kadlec on the Missouri Radio Network; Gary Thorme and Dave Norrie on ABC.

Ticket Availability

Some tickets remain by calling 1-800-CAT-PAWS (228-7297) or going online at www.mutigers.com

OKLAHOMA STATE at NEBRASKA

2:30 p.m. (CDT), Memorial Stadium/Osborne Field (73,918)

Lincoln, Neb. / ABC Regional Telecast
